Further disassembly revealed a loose and disconnected coil near the missing pin. To address potential bearing issues, the bearings were submerged in motor oil and a vacuum was applied.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with LEDs
item.description: During the ongoing restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the incandescent bulbs illuminating the RPM trimmer scales were replaced with LEDs for enhanced longevity. Custom-designed circuit boards housing SMD LEDs were crafted to seamlessly replace the original bulbs, ensuring a direct fit. These LED assemblies are offered to fellow enthusiasts, with an instructional video demonstrating their installation available online. The following images detail the RPM trimmer panel, initially showcasing the rear view with original bulbs in place.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of a Seized Solenoid to Tonearm Linkage
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I got from the UK had a seized linkage connecting the solenoid mechanism and tonearm. To lubricate this linkage, I had to disassemble the sensor arm assembly and remove it. Further inspection showed that the linkage’s rotating pin was stuck and had detached from its press-fit socket within the sensor arm base. I’ve created a video illustrating the problem and the repair process:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Linear Tracking System
item.description: My restoration project of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable started with the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. These mechanisms often require attention because of hardened lubricants and misadjusted tracking sensors. After taking the mechanism apart for cleaning and lubrication, I addressed the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm, which commonly experiences stiffness due to hardened lubricants. The sensor arm was then removed for disassembly to further work on the linkage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): New Cabinet Guiding Washers and Transport Lock Bushings
item.description: To finalize the mechanical repairs on this Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable, new transport lock bushings were necessary. These bushings ensure the sub-chassis is properly aligned within the upper and lower lock positions. This particular Beogram was missing these bushings, with no indication they were ever there. This photo shows the left transport lock disassembled: The bushing should be located in the opening on the sub-chassis arm on the right. The first step of the replacement bushing installation is shown here:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of a Broken SO ('Shut Off') Switch
item.description: This post continues the discussion about a malfunctioning “Shut Off” (SO) switch, which was missing a crucial plastic part, causing issues with the deck’s shutdown process. To address this, a 3D printed replacement part was designed and created. The “End Switch” (ES), still equipped with its plastic component, is pictured alongside the SO switch, highlighting the missing element. Creating a functional replacement part was challenging due to its small size and the limitations of the 3D printer.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Some Microsurgery on Disconnected Pickup Coils
item.description: I recently obtained a DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002 located in Norway. The motor required repair. The owner had already performed the ‘oil infusion’ procedure for the Oilite bearings. However, after reassembling and reinstalling the motor into the Beogram, the platter’s speed was excessively high and could not be adjusted. This image displays the motor, without the pulley, in the condition I received it: Uncontrollably high speed in a DC platter motor usually indicates a problem with one or both of the RPM feedback pickup coils within the motor, assuming the motor control circuit is functioning correctly.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Installation of New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: The last step in restoring my Beogram 4002 (5523) was replacing the old and slightly corroded RCA plugs. The picture highlights the original plugs: This image showcases the new gold-plated Amphenol RCA plugs during installation: The straightforward design of these plugs, which simplifies installation and ensures solid solder connections, is something I appreciate. And here is the finished product: I need to wait for the PCBs for my new RIAA phono preamp design, so there will be a slight delay.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Degraded Transport Lock Bushings and Missing Cabinet Guiding Washers
item.description: The Beogram 4002 restoration involved addressing the common issue of fragile orange transport lock bushings and missing cabinet guiding washers. Many Beograms used plastic washers, which are prone to cracking and falling apart. This was evident in the restoration project, as some washers were missing entirely. To rectify this, five new 3D-printed washers were installed. For aesthetic purposes, using a black washer for the front-center position is recommended to avoid visibility through the gap between the aluminum panel and the plinth.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Exchanging all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: After finishing most of the mechanical work, it was time to start repairing the electronics on a Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable. Replacing all electrolytic capacitors is recommended, as their internal fluid often leaks or dries up. I use high-quality Japanese capacitors to ensure my repairs last as long as possible. Tantalum capacitors, in particular, must be replaced because they can fail dramatically if a short circuit occurs, potentially damaging the circuit board.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor, Main PCB and RPM Adjustment Panel
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, experiencing RPM fluctuations, recently arrived from a customer for repair. The restoration process involved addressing issues with the DC platter motor, the main PCB, and the RPM adjustment panel. The platter motor was disassembled to lubricate the bearings. After immersing them in oil and applying a vacuum, the bearings were left undisturbed for two days to ensure proper saturation. Once the bubbling ceased, indicating full replenishment, the bearings were extracted and the motor was reassembled.

item.title: Beogram 4002 and 4004 DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently acquired two DC motors from Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables located in Denmark. My typical first step is an oil infusion process to address RPM fluctuations, a common issue. The 4002 motor arrived in this condition: Disassembly revealed the following: The two small, donut-shaped brass bearings, visible on the black pad, were submerged in motor oil under a vacuum. Bubbles appeared immediately, indicating the oil infusion process was working.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Repair of 'Knocking' AC Motor
item.description: I prefer to thoroughly test restored Beograms to ensure they’re free of intermittent issues. It’s not uncommon for new problems to appear with regular use. This was the case with a recently restored AC motor Beogram 4002 (5501). After playing a few records, I detected a faint knocking sound coming from inside the turntable. Upon removing the aluminum plates, I discovered the knocking synchronized with the AC motor’s rotation. Adjusting the motor tilt provided temporary noise reduction, but the knocking always returned, intensifying with each record played until it was noticeable during quieter tracks—an unacceptable issue for a turntable!

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Repair of a Damaged Pickup Coil and Oil Infusion
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from Australia was sent in for repair. The owner reported the motor always ran at high speed, suggesting a broken RPM feedback coil. Without this feedback, the motor receives maximum power and spins as fast as possible. Disassembly revealed the motor’s brushes were improperly installed and a solder burn marked one terminal. The small pickup coils, responsible for sending an AC voltage proportional to motor RPM, were also examined.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Completing the Restoration
item.description: During the summer of 2019, I had the opportunity to work on a Beogram 4002 turntable from Virginia, specifically restoring its DC platter motor. I recently received the entire unit for a complete overhaul. The arm lowering mechanism had been previously restored and was in excellent condition. My attention turned to the remaining areas needing restoration. To begin, I tackled the main PCB. The first photo illustrates its original condition:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning the Carriage Position Switches and Fixing a Bent Output Switch Contact Tab
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000, a process known as “switch day” involves cleaning the contacts of the many open switches. While some recommend desoldering the switches for thorough cleaning, it’s generally sufficient to clean the contact areas directly. This minimizes the risk of damaging the delicate contact tabs. Effective switch functionality hinges on clean contact points, not the overall appearance of the switch. The contact tabs should be straight and have adequate spring to ensure proper contact.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulb of the Tracking Sensor with a Drop-In LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 400x turntable, it’s common to replace the tracking sensor’s incandescent bulb with a more durable LED assembly. A drop-in replacement for the Beogram 4002 and 4004 models has been created and documented, while the Beogram 4000 version incorporates a Bang & Olufsen-specified intensity trimmer for fine-tuning the tracking feedback system’s sensitivity. It’s crucial to recalibrate the tracking sensor’s position after any light source replacement to maintain accurate tracking sensitivity.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors, RPM Relay and Trimmers on the Main PCB
item.description: Following the DC motor rebuild on this Beogram 4002 (5513), the main PCB was addressed. All electrolytic capacitors were swapped with high-quality, Japanese-made, 105C-rated capacitors. The existing Tantalum capacitors, known for their tendency to fail dramatically, were preemptively replaced with modern equivalents to avoid any potential issues. Images illustrate the original board and the sections targeted for capacitor replacement. The author designed a replacement for the original Siemens relay using a modern, fully encapsulated SMD relay.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - The Influence of C10 on RPM Stability
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 DC motor was prepped for restoration. The process began by removing the bearings for an oil infusion. The small brass bearings were submerged in motor oil, and a vacuum was applied. Bubbling indicated that the oil was being drawn into the bearings. These bearings took longer than usual, approximately 48 hours, for the bubbling to cease. After the bubbling stopped, the bearings were taken out of the oil

item.title: Beogram 4000: Glueing a Delaminated Platter Back Together and Installation of New Cabined Guidance Washers
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently working on was unfortunately damaged during shipping due to inadequate packaging by the seller. Because the platter wasn’t secured, it moved around and ultimately split into two pieces. The images show the separated top and bottom sections of the platter. Examining the platter’s interior reveals interesting details about its construction. The heavier bottom section of each platter was individually balanced, much like car tires. This involved drilling away small amounts of material from the heavier side, as evidenced by the red pen marks near the drill holes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with an SMD LED Light Source and Adjustment of the Feedback Sensisitivy
item.description: This Beogram 4002 turntable had a damaged part (the tracking sensor aperture) that was bent and obstructing the arm’s movement. This issue prevented the tracking system from working correctly. The initial setup used an incandescent light bulb: Upon removing the bulb housing, it was evident that the aperture was bent and rubbing against the optical sensor housing: The aperture was carefully straightened, and the bulb assembly was replaced with a new SMD LED light source.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration and Adjustment of AC Platter Motor
item.description: After restoring the electronics of a Beogram 4000 turntable, attention turned to the AC platter motor. This model features an older pulley design without built-in belt guards, relying instead on separate guards added to the motor mounting posts. These added guards are not essential, as the pulley’s shape effectively secures the belt. Motor tilt allows for adjustments to the belt’s vertical positioning. Like the DC motors in later Beogram models, the AC motors can also suffer from dried-out bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Restoration and a Test Spin with Oscar Peterson
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 turntable from Sweden in very corroded condition. To address the extensive corrosion, I chose to use another 4000 unit as a donor for parts. The donor unit, while missing some components, was free of corrosion. My restoration process started with the carriage. I disassembled and cleaned the arm lowering system, damper, carriage rods, and spindle in an ultrasonic bath. Additionally, the sensor arm assembly was removed to lubricate the damper-to-arm linkage pivot point.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs - New Capacitors, RPM Trimmers and RPM Relay
item.description: Following the replacement of the motor and reservoir capacitors in the Beogram 4000 restoration, the next step involved rebuilding the PCBs. This typically involves replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM trimmers, and the RPM relay. The main PCB, which is difficult to remove due to its hardwiring, was ‘flipped’ for component replacement. After replacing the components, the rebuilt board was ready for installation. A new relay was used, as the original Siemens relays often experience oxidation, hindering proper RPM switching.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of the Bearings and a Shiny New Pulley from Austria
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 DC platter motor in need of repair came to my workshop from Virginia. Here’s a picture of the motor: The motor’s pulley was unusually worn, with a groove where the raised center, designed to keep the belt aligned, should be: It barely functioned during the initial test. To address this, I disassembled it to lubricate the bearings: The bearings are the two small rings on the black surface.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the AC Motor Voltage and Measuring the Voltage Differences Between the Phases
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, the AC motor requires precise adjustment. The service manual recommends setting the main phase voltage to 6V (RMS) and the frequency to 42.3 Hz for 33 RPM using an oscilloscope. To observe both motor phases, connect the oscilloscope probes across the phase capacitor. Begin the adjustment by setting the 33 RPM trimmer on the control panel to its neutral position. This allows for fine-tuning the RPM offset potentiometer on the main PCB to achieve the target 42.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the PCBs and Restoring the 33 RPM Function
item.description: Typically, my restoration process for Beogram 4002 turntables begins with the arm lowering and tracking systems. However, this particular Beogram 4002 (5513) required a different approach. The control system needed attention, so I opted to address the PCBs first. Upon unpacking the turntable, I discovered that the platter motor would power on as soon as it was plugged in. This unusual behavior was caused by the seller connecting the motor to the standby LED header on the circuit board – a connection point rarely used on the 5513 boards.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with the Bill Evans Trio
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable from a Massachusetts customer. The initial evaluation can be found here. The restoration began by addressing the carriage system. This involved cleaning hardened lubricants from various parts like the arm lowering mechanism, rods, spindle, linkages, and damper, and applying modern synthetic lubricants. A key aspect of the Beogram 4000 is its solenoid-activated switches, which frequently experience oxidation and require attention. The contact terminals were removed and re-plated with nickel and gold-cobalt alloy for optimal performance and corrosion resistance.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4002 DC motor from France that needed some repair. My typical first step is to rejuvenate the oil-impregnated brass bearings by submerging them in oil. This process is usually successful in restoring motor function. This image displays the motor in its initial condition upon arrival: To access the bearings, I took the motor apart: The bearings are the two small ring-shaped components on the black surface.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of Main and Output Printed Circuit Boards, and a New Reservoir Capacitor
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration continued with a focus on the PCBs after addressing the decayed transport lock bushings. The main PCB was first, as shown below: In addition to replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM relay and trimmers were targeted due to their susceptibility to corrosion and impact on RPM stability. The following image highlights the RPM section in its initial condition: Modern, encapsulated 25-turn trimmers replaced the old ones, and a new relay was installed (interested enthusiasts can obtain a replacement relay by email or through the contact form).

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Original Dual Main Capacitor
item.description: While restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513), I had the chance to improve my design for a replacement part for the reservoir capacitor. This part lets me use two modern, high-temperature Japanese capacitors in place of the original dual-capacitor unit, which is no longer available. My previous design worked, but this new version is more robust and easier to 3D print. I’m getting better at designing for 3D printing; for instance, I learned to minimize overhangs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of Bearings and Installation of New Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor, in need of restoration, arrived from Washington state. Initial examination showed it needed some work. A bench test confirmed the bearings were squeaking, a common issue. The motor was disassembled to remove the bearings for lubrication. The bearings were placed in motor oil under a vacuum. This process forces air out of the bearing material and allows oil to penetrate it. After a few days, the bearings were removed from the oil.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor Bearings with Oil Infusion Under Vacuum
item.description: I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable and decided to address the DC motor while it’s open. Previously, I hadn’t realized the importance of properly lubricating the motor bearings for long-term stability. Simply applying grease provided a temporary fix, but RPM fluctuations would reappear after a few weeks. This time, I completely disassembled the motor to access the bearings. To ensure proper lubrication, I used a vacuum method with a mason jar and a FoodSaver pump.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the DC Motor
item.description: Following the reconstruction of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, I shifted my focus to the electronics, starting with the motor. While the turntable’s RPM stability was excellent, I believe a thorough restoration involves servicing every part, including the motor, to ensure long-term reliability and everyday usability. The initial step involved extracting the motor from its housing: Next, I removed the motor from its noise shield: and proceeded to disassemble it:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Tracking Force and Replacing the Strange Original Front Center Cabinet Guiding Washer
item.description: My Beogram 4000 restoration is complete, and it’s playing beautifully. As I write this, I’m enjoying “Song for My Father” by Horace Silver on a reissue, as original pressings are unfortunately outside my budget these days. One of the final tasks was refining the Beogram’s mechanics. I calibrated the tonearm weight and limits and replaced the guiding washer, which ensures the plinth moves smoothly. The original washer, pictured below, has a design flaw that was later corrected in the Beogram 400x series.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: The initial phase of the Beogram 4000 restoration involved the arm’s lowering and tracking mechanisms. The solenoid and damper, essential for the arm’s smooth and controlled descent onto the record, were revealed. Each part was carefully removed, cleaned, and lubricated. Attention then turned to the linkage connecting the damper plunger to the tonearm. Located on the sensor arm’s side, it required the arm’s removal to access and lubricate the linkage’s pivot point.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjusting Chassis, Platter, Tonearm Limits and Tracking Force
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is nearly complete. After adjusting the sub-chassis and platter, I set the tonearm limits and calibrated the tracking force. It’s crucial to finalize the platter height before adjusting the arm, ensuring the correct arm-to-platter distance. My YouTube channel has videos demonstrating platter bearing and sub-chassis adjustments, particularly for the Beogram 4000, but the 4002 process is similar. Here’s the result: The platter is now centered and level within the main aluminum plate.
